subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_0067_01C9D18E.48EC59A0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

You can actually tell if the bytes themselves are different? If so, that wo=
uld definitely satisfy me that everything was the same.

  ----- Original M=
essage ----- 
  From: Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, Ma=
y 10, 2009 4:32 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION =
JON





        If the audio had been resampled, you could expect less byt=
es, or different bytes, but not the same number of the same bytes.  That's =
why comparing the bytes in both files can rule that out, if no changes are =
found.



        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombie=
ghostresearch.com> wrote:


          From: April Abercrombie <april@abercr=
ombieghostresearch.com>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rul=
es-ATTENTION JON
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sund=
ay, May 10, 2009, 3:27 PM



          Yeah-I know about the file size comp=
arison. Obviously if the file size became smaller, we know for sure there h=
as been loss, except if the file had been saved to a lossless compression t=
ype, such as from RAW to TIFF in photo files.

          I just don't fully=
 trust the bit comparison because I don't trust that the bytes haven't been=
 resampled using interpolation, such as we discussed earlier. But that is l=
argely because I have no clue at that level of things what is actually goin=
g on.

          All I know about this I know from Graphic Design experienc=
e and working with photo files, so I only have that knowledge to use to com=
pare. I no nothing about actual programming language, Unix, or stuff like t=
hat.

          April

            ----- Original Message ----- 
          =
  From: Rj 
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sun=
day, May 10, 2009 4:13 PM
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading=
 rules-ATTENTION JON


                  They are not necessarily the same =
bytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to see if the files were in t=
he same ballpark.  Look at it the other way: if the number of bytes were DI=
FFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD changed, and you could stop testing.=
  But if the number of bytes are the same, it tends to indicate the files a=
re likely the same, but you still need a low level file comparison to be su=
re.

                  My method is to compare the files using the CMP comm=
and in unix.  There are many programs to compare files, but you have to be =
careful not to use one that does a line-by-line compare (or a comparison me=
ant for text files), since text files can be different at a low level, but =
look essential the same in an editor (because of the way spaces and tabs an=
d new lines work between editors and platforms).

                  But any=
way, the way to compare is with a program that can compare binary files, no=
t text files.


                  --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <a=
pril@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                    From: Apr=
il Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                    S=
ubject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                  =
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 20=
09, 2:42 PM



                    So if the number of bytes match then the=
y are the same bytes? See where my confusion comes in?

                   =
 How does one do a bit-level comparison? Is there a program that does that,=
 or is there some way of comparison by looking at the file's properties?

 =
                     ----- Original Message ----- 
                      Fr=
om: Rj 
                      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
               =
       Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:35 PM
                      Subject: Re=
: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON


                          =
  A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes (and their bits) in=
 the file.  If the file's content integrity is changed, that is, by definit=
ion, changing the bytes.  If the bytes in there are not changed, then that =
integrity has not changed.

                            It is possible to m=
ess with other things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or its owner=
ship) but this does not effect the contents, and so would not affect that i=
ntegrity, or the sound of the file (assuming you could read it at all after=
 changing the ownership, or the suffix, etc).

                            =
When you do your tests, if you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would re=
commend at least checking the file sizes.  If they are identical, there is =
a very high probability that the content has not changed.




             =
               --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh =
ostresearch. com> wrote:


                              From: April Abercr=
ombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                              =
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                 =
             To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                              Dat=
e: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:28 PM



                              Admittedl=
y I do not know much about bit-level comparisons, what they can or can't sh=
ow so I will have to leave that to you. I have doubts because I worry once =
a file's integrity has been messed with, I wonder that even though the bits=
 match, maybe that doesn't mean they are the same quality as the original. =
I really don't know though what is possible or impossible when it comes to =
this area.

                              "It is probably possible to set u=
p an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tes=
ts show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we ca=
n do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment would =
be very unusual."

                              The problem I have is that=
 not just from Jon, but I have heard it from other people, and a profession=
al and they all said that loss is possible. From all that, my conclusion wa=
s that maybe in some cases loss was possible.

                            =
  However, your arguments do put doubt back into my mind, which pisses me o=
ff, because I had originally argued feverishly for no loss, then I heard di=
fferent from different sources and decided to do what I thought was the rig=
ht thing by contacting a third party professional. So after all that, I dec=
ided I was licked and had to eat crow.

                              Now I=
 am back at square one, from the other side LOL!!! Computer people have bee=
n wrong in the past.


                              "It is probably possib=
le to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compressi=
on.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test your s=
etup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an attach=
ment would be very unusual."

                              I have not test=
ed it from my computer, as I haven't had any problems with loss. I would re=
ally like to have Jon work with us on this, because he was the original per=
son who told me I was wrong.

                              But I will test=
 it from my side. I will send a wav file to one of my other addresses. Then=
 I will download and compare. If I think I hear a difference, then maybe I =
can have you do a bit-level comparison on the files.

                     =
         Either way, I am going to get to the bottom of this.



          =
                      ----- Original Message ----- 
                       =
         From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups =
.com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
  =
                              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-A=
TTENTION JON


                                Yes you can tell loss of qua=
lity by a bit-level comparison.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, tha=
t is later interpreted by an audio player.  Two files with the exact same c=
ontents, whether they are audio or image or a dababase or an exe, are indis=
tinguishable from each other.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to =
a new file, and the contents of the other to a new file, and asked you whic=
h file each came from, there would be no way to tell.  Even the audio playe=
r could not tell.  The data is identical, and so the sound (or the picture,=
 etc) would be identical.

                                Yes I did listen=
 to the results, but that is not the best test (they sounded identical, but=
 that is a subjective opinion).  The real test is compring the contents.  I=
dentical contents means indentical data, means identical audio.

          =
                      It is probably possible to set up an email compressio=
n scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does=
 not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From w=
hat I see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual.


  =
                              --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april=
@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                F=
rom: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
             =
                   Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JO=
N
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
            =
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



                =
                I have not personally experienced the loss myself. Jon from=
 this list is the one who originally told me about it. I have also heard of=
 it happening to a few other people. After my conversation with Jon, I talk=
ed to a computer professional, and he told me that you can experience loss =
in attached files.

                                I don't know if you wou=
ld be able to tell loss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level compar=
ison. Just because the data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is p=
erfect.

                                Did you listen to the before and a=
fter results?

                                Jon-Please relay your experi=
ence with the loss of quality on emailed files.


                         =
       ----- Original Message ----- 
                                From: =
Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
         =
                       Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
                 =
               Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


              =
                  I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just di=
d some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once al=
lowing compression, and once turning it off.   I was able to verify that on=
e was compressed and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived a=
t Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of t=
he original, and the ones sent around email.  They were all identical, whic=
h indicates lossless compression.

                                If you h=
ave a file you'd like me to test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take=
 someone's word for how your server's work, without testing them yourself.
=



                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <=
april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                            =
    From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
        =
                        Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
       =
                         To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                     =
           Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



                        =
        For executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the comp=
ression during email is not loss less. 

                                I =
used to think as you do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file would=
 not loose anything. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I =
learned that I was wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first =
place is that when I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it =
in very small segments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of t=
ransfer. But because of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

 =
                               Now it may be in some cases, depending on th=
e servers or what have you that the file goes through, that the loss may be=
 less or more. But once the attachment is downloaded, the quality has been =
found to be less then the original wav.

                                Ag=
ain though you can only really tell when the wav file is large.

          =
                      ----- Original Message ----- 
                       =
         From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups =
.com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
  =
                              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules

=

                                The kind of compression that occurs during=
 an email attachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without l=
osing information.  For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, and=
 I sent it over email, it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, =
the resulting exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed on=
 the other side.

                                This kind of compression =
does things like looking for common patterns in the file, and replacing the=
m with a token.  A rough example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a=
 file 20 times, it could replace all the occurances with say $HN1.  And als=
o write a little dictionary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neig=
hbor".

                                When the file gets to its destinati=
on it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "Ho=
wdy Neighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it onl=
y needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

                      =
          Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending on =
the level of compression, some level of data is lost, and so cannot be reco=
vered or reconstructed later.

                                Rick



    =
                            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@a=
bercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                Fro=
m: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
               =
                 Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
              =
                  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                            =
    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                               =
 Another thing:

                                I recently found this out.=
 When you email a file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the emai=
l filtering process will actually compress the file automatically.

       =
                         So even if you have attached a wav. file, it will =
loose resolution over the email process. It will not sound exactly the same=
 as the original wav. file. How much it differs depends on the size of the =
file you are attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound much diff=
erent.

                                The only exception to this is if th=
e wav. file is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It h=
as to be pretty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the=
 threshold).

                                The best way to share files o=
ver the internet if you want them as close to the original as possible is t=
o upload them directly to a website.

                                -----=
 Original Message ----- 
                                From: Rj 
        =
                        To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                     =
           Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                            =
    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                        =
        Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine ta=
king a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixeli=
zation to the picture.  Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flow=
ers there at all.  You would see a lot of colored blocks.

                =
                Or in the other direction, imagine you are looking at a com=
petely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truely=
 random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, you would again start=
 to see colored blocks.

                                What's happening i=
s that it is processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the ave=
rage value of that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area w=
ith the average.  In video processing, this would result in a field of mult=
i-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish blo=
ck, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replace=
 all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did n=
ot know beforehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether=
 your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with =
clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

                                It wo=
rks the same with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as speech, =
and replacing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farther=
 you go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same t=
o random static will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fluctua=
ting square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could have=
 fun sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





       =
                         --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yaho=
o.com> wrote:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletbab=
ea@ yahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File =
uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .co=
m
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


   =
                             I always save the whole file in wav format the=
n do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

            =
                    As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos t=
o say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of w=
hite noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film,=
 no recording done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all intere=
sting.

                                Just a thought. Ok off to work now!=

                                Misty

                                ---=
 On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                       =
         From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                                Sub=
ject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To=
: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, Ma=
y 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                                Be a bit careful of =
formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though.=
   While some formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way =
it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose s=
ome of the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in music, where the a=
udio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources with a lot of n=
oise (like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize n=
on-sounds (like white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

   =
                             So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, onc=
e you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  B=
ut mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many false pos=
itives and misinterpretations.

                                --- On Sun,=
 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                    =
            From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                     =
           Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                    =
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Da=
te: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM


                                Thanks =
=3D)

                                 You will get the hang of it. Kristen=
 is right thats how you save it. For most softwares its under save as or ex=
port as. If you still have trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya=
 out.

                                Misty

                             =
   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:

Y>

                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>They are not necessa=
rily the same bytes, but I 
                  was proposing a quick check j=
ust to see if the files were in 
                  the same ballpark. =
 Look at it the other way: if the 
                  number of bytes were D=
IFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD 
                  changed, and you=
 could stop testing.  But if the number 
                  of bytes ar=
e the same, it tends to indicate the files are 
                  likely th=
e same, but you still need a low level file 
                  comparison t=
o be sure.<BR><BR>My method is to compare the 
                  files usin=
g the CMP command in unix.  There are many 
                  programs=
 to compare files, but you have to be careful not to 
                  use=
 one that does a line-by-line compare (or a comparison 
                  m=
eant for text files), since text files can be different at a 
             =
     low level, but look essential the same in an editor (because 
        =
          of the way spaces and tabs and new lines work between editors 
  =
                and platforms).<BR><BR>But anyway, the way to compare is wi=
th 
                  a program that can compare binary files, not text 
  =
                files.<BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie=
 
                  <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com></I></B>=

     =
                     <TD vAlign=3Dtop>A file's content, it's integrity, is =

                            simply the bytes (and their bits) in the file.=
  
                            If the file's content integrity is chan=
ged, that is, 
                            by definition, changing the byte=
s.  If the 
                            bytes in there are not changed=
, then that integrity 
                            has not changed.<BR><BR>=
It is possible to mess with 
                            other things about=
 a file (like its name, its 
                            suffix, or its own=
ership) but this does not effect 
                            the contents,=
 and so would not affect that 
                            integrity, or th=
e sound of the file (assuming you 
                            could read i=
t at all after changing the ownership, 
                            or the =
suffix, etc).<BR><BR>When you do your tests, 
                            i=
f you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would 
                          =
  recommend at least checking the file sizes.  If 
                   =
         they are identical, there is a very high probability 
            =
                that the content has not 
                            chang=
ed.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, 
                           =
 April Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombiegh 
                            =
ostresearch. com></I></B> wrote:<BR>

UOTE

                    <TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Y=
es you can tell loss of quality 
                                by a bit-l=
evel comparison.  An audio file 
                                is ju=
st a file of bytes, that is later 
                                interpre=
ted by an audio player.  Two files 
                                wi=
th the exact same contents, whether they are 
                             =
   audio or image or a dababase or an exe, are 
                           =
     indistinguishable from each other.  That 
                       =
         is, if I copied the contents of one to a new 
                    =
            file, and the contents of the other to a new 
                 =
               file, and asked you which file each came from, 
            =
                    there would be no way to tell.  Even the 
        =
                        audio player could not tell.  The data is 
   =
                             identical, and so the sound (or the picture, 
=
                                etc) would be identical.<BR><BR>Yes I did l=
isten 
                                to the results, but that is not the =
best test 
                                (they sounded identical, but tha=
t is a 
                                subjective opinion).  The real=
 test is 
                                compring the contents.  Iden=
tical contents 
                                means indentical data, mean=
s identical 
                                audio.<BR><BR>It is probably p=
ossible to set up 
                                an email compression sch=
eme that does do lossy 
                                audio compression.&=
nbsp; My tests show my setup 
                                does not.&nbs=
p; If you'd like me to help test 
                                your setu=
p, we can do that too. From what I see, 
                                lo=
ssy compression from an attachment would be 
                              =
  very unusual.<BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, 
                       =
         April Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombiegh 
                    =

        <TBODY>

                      =
          <TD vAlign=3Dtop>I can't vouch for your computer 
               =
                 or servers, but I just did some tests, and sent 
         =
                       a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, 
      =
                          once allowing compression, and once turning it 
 =
                               off.   I was able to verify that o=
ne 
                                was compressed and one was not, by chec=
king the 
                                sizes when they arrived at Yahoo.=
 Once they came 
                                back to MSN, I then did a =
bit-level comparison 
                                of the original, and =
the ones sent around 
                                email.  They wer=
e all identical, which 
                                indicates lossless =
compression.<BR><BR>If you 
                                have a file you=
'd like me to test for you, let 
                                me know.&n=
bsp; But I wouldn't take someone's 
                                word fo=
r how your server's work, without testing 
                                =
them yourself.<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                             =
   5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                                <I><april=
@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                                com></I></B=
> wrote:<BR>

=3Dygrp-text>
                                <P></P>
                     =
           <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">For 
                   =
             executables, you may be right. However, for wav 
             =
                   files, the compression during email is not loss 
       =
                         less. </FONT></DIV>
                              =
  <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                                face=3D"Myriad Pro">=
</FONT> </DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 fac=
e=3D"Myriad Pro">I used to 
                                think as you do=
, in that the emailed 
                                attachment of a=
 wav file would not loose 
                                anything. After =
a lengthy discourse with another 
                                member he=
re, I learned that I was wrong. The 
                                reason=
 why I did not realize it in the 
                                firs=
t place is that when I would email a wav 
                                f=
ile, I would intentionally keep it in very 
                               =
 small segments, to keep file size down. This was 
                        =
        just for ease of transfer. But because of this, 
                  =
              I had not experienced any noticeable 
                       =
         loss.</FONT></DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=
=3D2 
                                face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DI=
V>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">=
Now it may 
                                be in some cases, depending on =
the servers or 
                                what have you that the file=
 goes through, that 
                                the loss may be less o=
r more. But once the 
                                attachment is 
      =
                          downloaded, the quality has been 
=
                                found to be less then the original 
       =
                         wav.</FONT></DIV>
                                =
<DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                                face=3D"Myriad Pro"></=
FONT> </DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=
=3D"Myriad Pro">Again though 
                                you can only =

                           =
     <TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>The kind of comp=
ression that 
                                occurs during an email attach=
ment is "lossless": 
                                it compress the file c=
leverly without losing 
                                information.  =
For example, if I had a 
                                program in some .e=
xe files, and I sent it over 
                                email, it cou=
ld compress it.  But if it 
                                lost even =
one bit, the resulting exe file would 
                                not =
execute again after it was uncompressed on 
                               =
 the other side.<BR><BR>This kind of compression 
                         =
       does things like looking for common patterns in 
                   =
             the file, and replacing them with a token.  
            =
                    A rough example would be if it found "Howdy 
          =
                      Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace 
     =
                           all the occurances with say $HN1.  And also=
 
                                write a little dictionary in there somepl=
ace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".<BR>=
<BR>When the 
                                file gets to its destination =
it can be 
                                uncompressed, and all occurences=
 of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "Howdy Neighbor=
".  So it was 
                                compressed (instead of =
14 characters each, it 
                                only needed 4, plus=
 the dictionary), but lost no 
                                data.<BR><BR=
>Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                                are not =
lossless.  Depending on the level 
                                of =
compression, some level of data is lost, and 
                             =
   so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                               =
 later.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                        =
        5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                                <I><=
april@abercrombiegh ostresearch.
